THE MEETING PLACE â€” a metaphorical way of saying, here we musically present the best of two worlds, which are in some ways different, but yet one.

What a gem of a song â€” as two greats in African and Caribbean music join forces with the steel band, Siparia Deltones. Hugh Masekela with his distinctive voice and his seductive wind instrument; Machel Montano with his hypnotic voice and cadence; and Siparia Deltones with the pulsating allure of the steelpan, expertly played.

Enjoy this here then go download it properly.

Amazing Fusion. I love Konpa and dance to it all the time.  I was born and still live in London but have lived abroad and travelled elsewhere.  I love this fusion of Soca, Konpa and Zouk.  The track is a collaboration between Machel (Trini artist) and Problem Child (from St. Vincent & the Grenadines - where my parents are from)  I went to Notting Hill Carnival this year and it was nice.  Met people from all over the Caribbean (hello Curacao crew from the Netherlands).  I love Caribbean culture.   There is so much to be proud of.  Please continue to generate good vibes, culture, revenues, skills, expertise and of course the excellent music.  Half of St Vincent still has it's French town names and we still have indigenous Carib people in the north, much like our Dominican cousins (who also have a Carib settlement - but there's is well preserved and we are trying to hang on to ours).  Big up everyone from the Caribbean (and not just in the islandsthe .  We are spread far and wide to include all of the not so obvious places like Belize, Colombian coastline towns, the French, Dutch and English Guianas (Guyana) and the like.  We are definitely one people...The African Diaspora is extensive, talented, beautiful and so inclusive/ friendly.  Love from London to de world....

The World Mourns Babylonâ€™s Fall

For in one hour your judgment has come.â€™

11â€œAnd the merchants of the earth will weep and mourn over her, for no one buys their merchandise anymore: 12merchandise of gold and silver, precious stones and pearls, fine linen and purple, silk and scarlet, every kind of citron wood, every kind of object of ivory, every kind of object of most precious wood, bronze, iron, and marble; 13and cinnamon and incense, fragrant oil and frankincense, wine and oil, fine flour and wheat, cattle and sheep, horses and chariots, and bodies and souls of men. 14The fruit that your soul longed for has gone from you, and all the things which are rich and splendid have [g]gone from you, and you shall find them no more at all. 15The merchants of these things, who became rich by her, will stand at a distance for fear of her torment, weeping and wailing, 16and saying, â€˜Alas, alas, that great city that was clothed in fine linen, purple, and scarlet, and adorned with gold and precious stones and pearls! 17For in one hour such great riches [h]came to nothing.â€™ Every shipmaster, all who travel by ship, sailors, and as many as trade on the sea, stood at a distance 18and cried out when they saw the smoke of her burning, saying, â€˜What is like this great city?â€™

19â€œThey threw dust on their heads and cried out, weeping and wailing, and saying, â€˜Alas, alas, that great city, in which all who had ships on the sea became rich by her wealth! For in one hour she [i]is made desolate.â€™

20â€œRejoice over her, O heaven, and you [j]holy apostles and prophets, for God has avenged you on her!â€

Finality of Babylonâ€™s Fall
21Then a mighty angel took up a stone like a great millstone and threw it into the sea, saying, â€œThus with violence the great city Babylon shall be thrown down, and shall not be found anymore. 22The sound of harpists, musicians, flutists, and trumpeters shall not be heard in you anymore. 12â€œWhat do you think? If a man has a hundred sheep, and one of them goes astray, does he not leave the ninety-nine and go to the mountains to seek the one that is straying? 13And if he should find it, assuredly, I say to you, he rejoices more over that sheep than over the ninety-nine that did not go astray. 14Even so it is not the will of your Father who is in heaven that one of these little ones should perish.

Dealing with a Sinning Brother
15â€œMoreover if your brother sins against you, go and tell him his fault between you and him alone. If he hears you, you have gained your brother. 16But if he will not hear, take with you one or two more, that â€˜by the mouth of two or three witnesses every word may be established.â€™ 17And if he refuses to hear them, tell it to the church. But if he refuses even to hear the church, let him be to you like a heathen and a tax collector.

18â€œAssuredly, I say to you, whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven.

19â€œAgain[d] I say to you that if two of you agree on earth concerning anything that they ask, it will be done for them by My Father in heaven. 20For where two or three are gathered together in My name, I am there in the midst of them.â€

The Parable of the Unforgiving Servant
21Then Peter came to Him and said, â€œLord, how often shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? Up to seven times?â€

22Jesus said to him, â€œI do not say to you, up to seven times, but up to seventy times seven. 23Therefore the kingdom of heaven is like a certain king who wanted to settle accounts with his servants. 24And when he had begun to settle accounts, one was brought to him who owed him ten thousand talents. 25But as he was not able to pay, his master commanded that he be sold, with his wife and children and all that he had, and that payment be made. 26The servant therefore fell down before him, saying, â€˜Master, have patience with me, and I will pay you all.â€™ 27Then the master of that servant was moved with compassion, released him, and forgave him the debt.

28â€œBut that servant went out and found one of his fellow servants who owed him a hundred denarii; and he laid hands on him and took him by the throat, saying, â€˜Pay me what you owe!â€™ 29So his fellow servant fell down [e]at his feet and begged him, saying, â€˜Have patience with me, and I will pay you [f]all.â€™ 30And he would not, but went and threw him into prison till he should pay the debt. 31So when his fellow servants saw what had been done, they were very grieved, and came and told their master all that had been done. 32Then his master, after he had called him, said to him, â€˜You wicked servant! I forgave you all that debt because you begged me. 33Should you not also have had compassion on your fellow servant, just as I had pity on you?â€™ 34And his master was angry, and delivered him to the torturers until he should pay all that was due to him.

35â€œSo My heavenly Father also will do to you if each of you, from his heart, does not forgive his brother [g]his trespasses.â€

Jesus Blesses Little Children
13Then little children were brought to Him that He might put His hands on them and pray, but the disciples rebuked them. 14But Jesus said, â€œLet the little children come to Me, and do not forbid them; for of such is the kingdom of heaven.â€ 15And He laid His hands on them and departed from there.

Jesus Counsels the Rich Young Ruler
16Now behold, one came and said to Him, â€œGood[d] Teacher, what good thing shall I do that I may have eternal life?â€

17So He said to him, [e]â€œWhy do you call Me good? [f]No one is good but One, that is, God. But if you want to enter into life, keep the commandments.â€

Jesus said, â€œâ€˜You shall not murder,â€™ â€˜You shall not commit adultery,â€™ â€˜You shall not steal,â€™ â€˜You shall not bear false witness,â€™ 19â€˜Honor your father and your mother,â€™ and, â€˜You shall love your neighbor as yourself.â€™ â€

With God All Things Are Possible
23Then Jesus said to His disciples, â€œAssuredly, I say to you that it is hard for a rich man to enter the kingdom of heaven. 24And again I say to you, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God.â€

25When His disciples heard it, they were greatly astonished, saying, â€œWho then can be saved?â€

26But Jesus looked at them and said to them, â€œWith men this is impossible, but with God all things are possible.â€

28So Jesus said to them, â€œAssuredly I say to you, that in the regeneration, when the Son of Man sits on the throne of His glory, you who have followed Me will also sit on twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel. 29And everyone who has left houses or brothers or sisters or father or mother [h]or wife or children or [i]lands, for My nameâ€™s sake, shall receive a hundredfold, and inherit eternal life. 30But many who are first will be last, and the last first.
